image.altText: An image of Brittany Higgins next to an image of Bruce Lehrmann.

props.synopsis: The Federal Court has published final submissions made by Brittany Higgins in Bruce Lehrmann's defamation case against Network Ten and journalist Lisa Wilkinson.

title.children: Britanny Higgins gave 'unwavering' account of alleged rape throughout defamation trial: lawyer

image.altText: Man arrested over possessing child abuse material

props.synopsis: A registered sex offender is arrested at a property in Canberra, charged with possessing and transmitting child abuse material from several devices, and for failing to report as a registerable offender.

title.children: Registered sex offender arrested in Canberra, charged with possessing and transmitting child sexual abuse material

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann walking into court.

props.synopsis: A new date has been set for a judgment in the defamation case brought by former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann against Network Ten and Lisa Wilkinson, which was delayed last week when the network successfully applied to bring fresh evidence before the court.

title.children: Judgment in Bruce Lehrmann defamation case to be handed down on Monday

image.altText: A young boy in a blue hat plays with a toy train set.

props.synopsis: The mother of four-year-old Blake Corney, who died in an horrific crash on the Monaro Highway in Canberra, is suing the truck driver who ploughed into the family's car as they waited at a red light in 2018.

title.children: Mother of four-year-old Blake Corney suing truck driver who caused crash that killed her son

image.altText: A woman wearing a hat and white lannyard.

props.synopsis: Canberra's public health system is getting a new look with $1.5 million being spent on rebranding in a bid to make care services more accessible and to bolster staff recruitment efforts.Â

title.children: It took a year for Anni's nursing qualifications to be recognised in Australia. She says that needs to change

image.altText: A group of people holding Israeli flags.

props.synopsis: Israel'sÂ ultra-Orthodox communityÂ has always been exempt from mandatory military service but a ruling in the country's highest court has changed everything.

title.children: '200,000 Torah students' are allegedly protecting Israel. Critics say it's time they fought

image.altText: A sunny image of the grand front gate of Cranbrook private school

props.synopsis: A Cranbrook school teacher who has been on leave following Four Corners revelations has been temporarily banned from teaching in New South Wales schools.

title.children: Cranbrook teacher who allegedly sent graphic emails banned from teaching in NSW schools

image.altText: A wide shot of the front entrance to Casuarina Prison, with two men dressed in blue walking out and trees in the foreground.

props.synopsis: A coronial inquest into WA's first recorded death in youth custody has heard it's not possible to treat detainees lawfully and humanely at Unit 18.WARNING: This story contains the name and image of an Indigenous person who has died.

title.children: Inquest into death of Cleveland Dodd hears humane treatment impossible at notorious Unit 18

image.altText: A male seller surrounded by customers wearing hijab.

props.synopsis: A playful "takjil war" has erupted in Indonesia after non-Muslims started buying up snacks and food usually eaten to break the fast during Ramadan.

title.children: There's a 'war' happening in Indonesia that you probably don't know about

image.altText: A graphic of a thermometer and the globe indicating rising heat

props.synopsis: As the world continues its spell of hottest months on record, leading climate scientists say there is a margin to the persistent heat which cannot be explained by the effects of known climate drivers and global warming.

title.children: 'Uncharted territory': The world's extreme heat can't be fully explained, and scientists are worried

image.altText: A smiling young blonde woman with a drink in her hand sits in the sun.

props.synopsis: Lachlan Young, 21,Â has faced a packed courtroom in Ballarat. He is charged with the murder of 23-year-old Hannah McGuire, whose body was found in a burnt-out car last week.

title.children: Man accused of murdering Hannah McGuire faces court in Ballarat

image.altText: Two young women with crossed arms look at the camera.

props.synopsis: Adelaide now has the tightest rental market in the country, after overtaking Perth as the capital city with the lowest vacancy rate in Australia.

title.children: 'I'm a doctor ... still can't get a house': Adelaide overtakes Perth as tightest capital city rental market

image.altText: a boy toddler smiling into the camera

props.synopsis: Concerns were raised about the evidence against Aaron Harley James, including a problematic police interview of a minor.

title.children: Queensland man accused of killing toddler stepson declared innocent with charges dropped

image.altText: A man in a grey polo shirt stands in a green field under a blue sky.

props.synopsis: A western Victorian man is accused of altering the stone arrangement believed to be 1,500 years old, but he is disputing the site's history, suggesting it is not of Aboriginal origins.

title.children: Farmer charged with harming Aboriginal heritage after stones allegedly moved from giant eel arrangement

image.altText: People are splashing in a pool built on the foreshore.

props.synopsis: Tanya Plibersek has announced she plans to reject an apartment and retail development on an "internationally important" wetland at Queensland's Moreton Bay.

title.children: Controversial development on 'internationally important' wetland tentatively rejected

image.altText: A transgender woman walks past photographs outside a court house.

props.synopsis: Social media platform Giggle for Girls is being sued by transgender woman Roxanne Tickle after her access to the women-only app was revoked. The app's owner has denied Ms Tickle is a woman.

title.children: Transgender woman sues women-only social media platform she was excluded from

image.altText: Eva Lawler at an indoor press conference with flags in the background.

props.synopsis: The NT chief minister says the youth curfew in Alice Springs has been a "circuit breaker", leading to a reduction in crime and an increase in the number of families asking for support.

title.children: Alice Springs youth curfew extended by six nights to see out school holidays

image.altText: A sunset over solar panels and vineyards

props.synopsis: One of Australia's largest wineries, Casella Family Brands, has installed almost 9,000 solar panels â enough to power more than 1,900 homes.

title.children: Winery using more electricity than a small town turns to solar power as industry pushes to decarbonise

image.altText: A crowd of people face a brightly lit stage with the words 'Spilt Milk' atop it.

props.synopsis: While one music festival took a profit of almost $50 million, only 56 per cent of similar events are profitable, new research from Creative Australia has found.

title.children: More than one-third of Australian music festivals are not profitable, according to new data

image.altText: Photo of two mobile phones in people's hands

props.synopsis: Australians are on track for a government-issued digital ID. Most people seem relaxed, but it's the number one story on "alt social media".

title.children: Spooky theories on the big-bad-almost hack and an ugly window into the world of 'alt social media'

image.altText: Image of a high waterfall in a national park

props.synopsis: Police believe the 20-year-old was bushwalking when she slipped and fell more than 100 metres into a creek at Belmore Falls in the state's Southern Highlands.

title.children: Woman's body found three days after she fell from cliff at popular NSW waterfall

image.altText: An axe lying on a road that has been cordoned off by police.

props.synopsis: Paramedics found the 38-year-old with serious head injuries at Raymond Terrace early this morning. He died at the scene. A 29-year-old man has been taken into custody.

title.children: Man armed with axe dies after confrontation with man wielding Razor scooter, police allege

image.altText: Back of grey-haired woman's head at desk with computer screen and take-away coffee cup

props.synopsis: New analysis from KPMG shows how COVID has pushed more people over 55 back into the workforce, with the retirement age steadily increasing over the past 20 years.Â

title.children: The average retirement age in Australia is growing. An economist explains why

image.altText: An X-ray printout showing a pelvis with two hips replaced.

props.synopsis: Smart people are getting caught out on private health insuranceÂ â so do they need to be more savvy, or does the system need to change?Â

title.children: Australians seeking hip replacements tripped up by health insurance fine print

image.altText: A young John Farnham with long hair, smiling and wearing a leather jacket.

props.synopsis: Australian singing superstar John Farnham has announced the release of his memoir. After being asked many times, Farnham says "it finally felt like the right time to sit down and tell my story".

title.children: John Farnham to break his silence about personal life in new memoir

image.altText: Jack Wighton and Latrell Mitchell stand arm in arm at a South Sydney Rabbitohs NRL game.

props.synopsis: Jack Wighton is reluctant to discuss the plight of his Rabbitohs teammate Latrell Mitchell, who has apologised to his teammates after copping a three-match suspension.

title.children: 'A mate protects a mate': Jack Wighton comes to Latrell Mitchell's defence after ban

image.altText: A woman smiling and taking a selfie

props.synopsis: The alleged murder of Hannah McGuire, whose body was found in a burnt-out car near Ballarat last week, reignites calls to prevent violence against women and create a culture of respect and equality.Â Â

title.children: 'We cannot continue down this path': Anger and anguish as Ballarat mourns a bright star snuffed out

image.altText: Man leaning on bar with Peninsula Hotel sign in background

props.synopsis: A Far North Queensland town has been without a pub since its publican was killed by a crocodile a year ago. A long-time friend says he couldn't sit and watch his mate's hard work go to waste.

title.children: Mate moves 3,000km to reopen Cape York pub and revive legacy of publican killed by crocodile

image.altText: A wide angle shot of Risdon Prison in Tasmania.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian prisoner who committed a number of animal cruelty offences, including killing juvenile sparrows, while behind bars could potentially face more jail time.Â

title.children: Cruelty to birds could land Tasmanian inmate more jail time

image.altText: A man and a woman stand on a beach with their arms around each other. They have grave expressions on their faces.

props.synopsis: Peter Correy was tricked into sending $450,000 to an Australian oil company. A financial crime expert warns criminals are exploiting weaknesses in Australia's regulatory system to get away with laundering.

title.children: How criminals scammed a NSW couple out of $450k and used an Australian company to launder the money

image.altText: Anthony Albanese at a press conference.

props.synopsis: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese urges his Israeli counterpart to avoid a ground invasion of Rafah in southern Gaza, after Benjamin Netanyahu flagged a date had been set for the offensive.

title.children: Albanese urges Netanyahu to avoid Rafah invasion, questions why Gaza aid has taken so long

image.altText: Customers stand near the entrance of a shoe store called Vern's in a modern shopping mall

props.synopsis: Police confiscate more than 1,100 shoes across Malaysia ahead of the end of Ramadan after an outcry over the footwear's logo that resemblesÂ the word "Allah" in Arabic script.

title.children: 'Allah' shoes seized across Malaysia after outcry as fasting month of Ramadan approaches the end

image.altText: A woman with long brown hair stares directly in to a camera with a Palestinian flag behind her.

props.synopsis: Longevity has been a hallmark of the pro-Palestinian movement, with protests calling for a change in government policy held weekly since mid-October. The Jewish community and its supporters have also held regular vigils to remember those killed and taken hostage.

title.children: Six months on from the Hamas attack on Israel and war in Gaza, people in Australia are showing they haven't forgotten
